I see into thy end, and am almost
A man already.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: First, make yourself but like one,
Fore-thinking this. I have already fit
(It is in my Cloak-bag) Doublet, Hat, Hose, all
That answer to them: Would you in their serving,
(And with what imitation you can borrow
From youth of such a season) before Noble Lucius
Present yourself, desire his service: tell him
Wherein you are happy; which will make him know,
If that his head have ear in Music, doubtless
With joy he will embrace you: for he is Honourable,
And doubling that, most holy. Your means abroad:
You have me rich, and I will never fail
Beginning, nor supplement.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Thou art all the comfort
The Gods will diet me with. Prithee away,
There is more to be considered: but we will even
All that good time will give us. This attempt,
I am Soldier to, and will abide it with
A Princes Courage. Away, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Well Madam, we must take a short farewell,
Lest being missed, I be suspected of
Your carriage from the Court. My Noble Mistress,
Here is a box, I had it from the Queen,
What is in it is precious: If you are sick at Sea,
Or Stomach-qualmed at Land, a Dram of this
Will drive away distemper. To some shade,
And fit you to your Manhood: may the Gods
Direct you to the best.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Amen: I thank thee.

div2.head: Scena Quinta.
div2.stage:
Enter Cymbeline, Queene, Cloten, Lucius,
and Lords.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Thus far, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thanks, Royal Sir:
My Emperor hath wrote, I must from hence,
And am right sorry, that I must report ye
My Masters Enemy.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Our Subjects (Sir)
Will not endure his yoke; and for ourself
To show less Sovereignty than they, must needs
Appear un-Kinglike.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So Sir: I desire of you
A Conduct over Land, to Milford-Hauen.
Madam, all joy befall your Grace, and you.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: My Lords, you are appointed for that Office:
The due of Honour, in no point omit:
So farewell Noble Lucius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Your hand, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Receive it friendly: but from this time forth
I wear it as your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, the Event
Is yet to name the winner. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Leave not the worthy Lucius, good my Lords
Till he have crossed the Seuern. Happiness.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He goes hence frowning: but it honours us
That we have given him cause.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: It is all the better,
Your valiant Britaines have their wishes in it.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Lucius hath wrote already to the Emperor
How it goes here. It fits us therefore ripely
Our Chariots, and our Horsemen be in readiness:
The Powers that he already hath in Gallia
Will soon be drawn to head, from whence he moves
His war for Britaine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is not sleepy business,
But must be looked to speedily, and strongly.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Our expectation that it would be thus
Hath made us forward. But my gentle Queen,
Where is our Daughter? She hath not appeared
Before the Roman, nor to us hath tendered
The duty of the day. She look us like
A thing more made of malice, than of duty,
We have noted it. Call her before us, for
We have been too slight in sufferance.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Royal Sir,
Since the exile of Posthumus, most retired
Hath her life been: the Cure whereof, my Lord,
It is time must do. Beseech your Majesty,
Forbear sharpe speeches to her. She is a Lady
So tender of rebukes, that words are stroke;
And strokes death to her.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Where is she Sir? How
Can her contempt be answered?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Please you Sir,
Her Chambers are all locked, and there is no answer
That will be given to the loud of noise, we make.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Lord, when last I went to visit her,
She prayed me to excuse her keeping close,
Whereto constrained by her infirmity,
She should that duty leave unpaid to you
Which daily she was bound to proffer: this
She wished me to make known: but our great Court
Made me to blame in memory.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Her doors locked?
Not seen of late? Grant Heavens, that which I
Fear, prove false.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Son, I say, follow the King.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: That man of hers, Pisanio, her old Servant
I have not seen these two days.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Go, look after:
Pisanio, thou that standest so for Posthumus,
He hath a Drug of mine: I pray, his absence
Proceed by swallowing that. For he believes
It is a thing most precious. But for her,
Where is she gone? Happily despair hath seized her:
Or winged with fervor of her love, she is flown
To her desired Posthumus: gone she is,
To death, or to dishonour, and my end
Can make good use of either. She being down,
I have the placing of the Brittish Crown.
How now, my Son?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: It is certain she is fled:
Go in and cheer the King, he rages, none
Dare come about him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: All the better: may
This night fore-stall him of the coming day.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I love, and hate her: for she is Fair and Royal,
And that she hath all courtly parts more exquisite
Than Lady, Ladies, Woman, from every one
The best she hath, and she of all compounded
Out-sells them all. I love her therefore, but
Disdaining me, and throwing Favours on
The low Posthumus, slanders so her judgment,
That what is else rare, is choked: and in that point
I will conclude to hate her, nay indeed,
To be revenged upon her. For, when Fools shall ~~
Who is here? What, are you packing sirra?
Come hither: Ah you precious Pander, Villain,
Where is thy Lady? In a word, or else
Thou art straightaway with the Fiends.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: O, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Where is thy Lady? Or, by Iupiter,
I will not ask again. Close Villain,
I will have this Secret from thy heart, or rip
Thy heart to find it. Is she with Posthumus?
From whose so many weights of baseness, cannot
A dram of worth be drawn.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Alas, nay Lord,
How can she be with him? When was she missed?
He is in Rome.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Where is she Sir? Come nearer:
No farther halting: satisfy me home,
What is become of her?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: O, my all-worthy Lord.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: All-worthy Villain,
Discover where thy Mistress is, at once,
At the next word: no more of worthy Lord:
Speak, or thy silence on the instant, is
Thy condemnation, and thy death.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Then Sir:
This Paper is the history of my knowledge
Touching her flight.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let us see it: I will pursue her
Even to Augustus Throne.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Or this, or perish.
She is far enough, and what he learns by this,
May prove his travel, not her danger.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I will write to my Lord she is dead: O Imogen,
Safe mayst thou wander, safe return again.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Sirrah, is this Letter true?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Sir, as I think.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
It is Posthumus hand, I know it. Sirra, if thou
wouldst not be a Villain, but do me true service: undergo
those Employments wherein I should have cause to use
thee with a serious industry, that is, what villainy soever I
bid thee do to perform it, directly and truly, I would
think thee an honest man: thou shouldest neither want
my means for thy relief, nor my voice for thy preferment.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Well, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
Wilt thou serve me? For since patiently and
constantly thou hast stuck to the bare Fortune of that
Beggar Posthumus, thou canst not in the course of gratitude,
but be a diligent follower of mine. Wilt thou serve
me?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Give me thy hand, here is my purse. Hast any
of thy late Masters Garments in thy possession?

sp.speaker: Pisan.
sp.p:
I have (my Lord) at my Lodging, the same
Suite he wore, when he took leave of my Lady and Mistress.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The first service thou dost me, fetch that Suite
hither, let it be thy first service, go.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Meet thee at Milford-Hauen: (I forgot to ask
him one thing, I will remember it anon:) even there, thou
villain Posthumus will I kill thee. I would these Garments
were come. She said upon a time (the bitterness
of it, I now belch from my heart) that she held the very
Garment of Posthumus, in more respect, than my Noble
and natural person; together with the adornment of
my Qualities. With that Suite upon my back will I ravish
her: first kill him, and in her eyes; there shall she see
my valour, which will then be a torment to her contempt.
He on the ground, my speech of insulment ended on his
dead body, and when my Lust hath dined (which, as I
say, to vex her, I will execute in the Clothes that she so
praised:) to the Court I will knock her back, foot her home
again. She hath despised me rejoicingly, and I will be
merry in my Revenge.
Be those the Garments?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Aye, my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: How long is it since she went to Milford-Hauen?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: She can scarce be there yet.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Bring this Apparel to my Chamber, that is
the second thing that I have commanded thee. The third
is, that thou wilt be a voluntary Mute to my design. Be
but duteous, and true preferment shall tender itself to
thee. My Revenge is now at Milford, would I had wings
to follow it. Come, and be true.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Thou biddest me to my loss: for true to thee,
Were to prove false, which I will never be
To him that is most true. To Milford go,
And find not her, whom thou pursuest. Flow, flow
You Heavenly blessings on her: This Fools speed
Be crossed with slowness; Labour be his meed.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I see a man's life is a tedious one,
I have tired myself: and for two nights together
Have made the ground my bed. I should be sick,
But that my resolution helps me: Milford,
When from the Mountain top, Pisanio showed thee,
Thou wast within a ken. O Jove, I think
Foundations fly the wretched: such I mean,
Where they should be relieved. Two Beggars told me,
I could not miss my way. Will poor Folks lie
That have Afflictions on them, knowing it is
A punishment, or Trial? Yes; no wonder,
When Rich-ones scarce tell true. To lapse in Fullness
Is sorer, than to lie for Need: and Falsehood
Is worse in Kings, than Beggars. My dear Lord,
Thou art one of the false Ones: Now I think on thee,
My hunger is gone; but even before, I was
At point to sink, for Food. But what is this?
Here is a path to it: it is some savage hold:
I were best not call; I dare not call: yet Famine
Ere clean it over-throw Nature, makes it valiant.
Plenty, and Peace breeds Cowards: Hardness ever
Of Hardiness is Mother. Ho? who is here?
If anything that is civil, speak: if savage,
Take, or lend. Ho? No answer? Then I will enter.
Best draw my Sword; and if mine Enemy
But fear the Sword like me, he will scarcely look on it.
Such a Foe, good Heavens.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You Polidore have proved best Woodman, and
Are Master of the Feast: Cadwall, and I
Will play the Cook, and Servant, it is our match:
The sweat of industry would dry, and die
But for the end it works to. Come, our stomachs
Will make what is homely, savoury: Weariness
Can snore upon the Flint, when resty Sloth
Finds the down-pillow hard. Now peace be here,
Poor house, that keepest thyself.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I am thoroughly weary.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: I am weak with toil, yet strong in appetite.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: There is cold meat in the Cave, we will browse on that
Whilst what we have killed, be Cooked.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay, come not in:
But that it eats our victuals, I should think
Here were a Fairy.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: What is the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By Iupiter an Angel: or if not
An earthly Paragon. Behold Divineness
No elder than a Boy.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Good masters harm me not:
Before I entered here, I called, and thought
To have begged, or bought, what I have took: good troth
I have stolen naught, nor would not, though I had found
Gold strewed in the Floor. Here is money for my Meat,
I would have left it on the Board, so soon
As I had made my Meal; and parted
With Prayers for the Provider.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Money? Youth.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: All Gold and Silver rather turn to dirt,
As it is no better reckoned, but of those
Who worship dirty Gods.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I see you are angry:
Know, if you kill me for my fault, I should
Have died, had I not made it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Whether bound?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: To Milford-Hauen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Fidele Sir: I have a Kinsman, who
Is bound for Italy; he embarked at Milford,
To whom being going, almost spent with hunger,
I am fallen in this offence.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Prithee (fair youth)
Think us no Churls: nor measure our good minds
By this rude place we live in. Well encountered,
It is almost night, you shall have better cheer
Ere you depart; and thanks to stay, and eat it:
Boys, bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Were you a woman, youth,
I should woo hard, but be your Groom in honesty:
I bid for you, as I do buy.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: I will make it my Comfort
He is a man, I will love him as my Brother:
And such a welcome as I would give to him
(After long absence) such is yours. Most welcome:
Be sprightly, for you fall amongst Friends.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Amongst Friends?
If Brothers: would it had been so, that they
Had been my Fathers Sons, then had my prize
Been less, and so more equal ballasting
To thee Posthumus.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He wrings at some distress.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Would I could free it.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Or I, whatever it be,
What pain it cost, what danger: Gods!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hark Boys.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Great men
That had a Court no bigger than this Cave,
That did attend themselves, and had the virtue
Which their own Conscience sealed them: laying by
That nothing-gift of differing Multitudes
Could not out-peer these twain. Pardon me Gods,
I would change my sex to be Companion with them,
Since Leonatus false.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It shall be so:
Boys we will go dress our Hunt. Fair youth come in;
Discourse is heavy, fasting: when we have supped
We will mannerly demand thee of thy Story,
So far as thou wilt speak it.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Pray draw near .

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: The Night to the Owl,
And Morn to the Lark less welcome.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: I pray draw near .

div2.head: Scena Octaua.
div2.stage: Enter two Roman Senators, and Tribunes.

sp.speaker: 1.Sen.
sp.l: This is the tenor of the Emperors Writ;
That since the common men are now in Action
Against the Pannonians, and Dalmatians,
And that the Legions now in Gallia, are
Full weak to undertake our Wars against
The fallen-off Britaines, that we do incite
The Gentry to this business. He creates
Lucius pro-consul: and to you the Tribunes
For this immediate Levy, he commands
His absolute Commission. Long live Caesar.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Is Lucius General of the Forces?

sp.speaker: 2.Sen.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Remaining now in Gallia?

sp.speaker: 1.Sen.
sp.l: With those Legions
Which I have spoke of, whereunto your levy
Must be suppliant: the words of your Commission
Will tie you to the numbers, and the time
Of their dispatch.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: We will discharge our duty.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p:
I am near to the place where they should meet,
if Pisanio have mapped it truly. How fit his Garments
serve me? Why should his Mistress who was made by him
that made the Taylor, not be fit too? The rather (saving
reverence of the Word) for it is said a Woman's fitness
comes by fits: therein I must play the Workman, I dare
speak it to myself, for it is not Vainglory for a man,
and his Glass, to confer in his own Chamber; I mean,
the Lines of my body are as well drawn as his; no less
young, more strong, not beneath him in Fortunes, beyond
him in the advantage of the time, above him in
Birth, alike conversant in general services, and more remarkable
in single oppositions; yet this imperseverant
Thing loves him in my despite. What Mortality is?
Posthumus, thy head (which now is growing upon thy
shoulders) shall within this hour be off, thy Mistress enforced,
thy Garments cut to pieces before thy face: and
all this done, spurn her home to her Father, who may
(happily) be a little angry for my so rough usage: but my
Mother having power of his testiness, shall turn all into
my commendations. My Horse is tied up safe, out
Sword, and to a sore purpose: Fortune put them into my
hand: This is the very description of their meeting place
and the Fellow dares not deceive me.

div2.head: Scena Secunda.
div2.stage:
Enter Belarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus, and
Imogen from the Cave.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are not well: Remain here in the Cave,
We will come to you after Hunting.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Brother, stay here:
Are we not Brothers?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: So man and man should be,
But Clay and Clay, differs in dignity,
Whose dust is both alike. I am very sick,

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Go you to Hunting, I will abide with him.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: So sick I am not, yet I am not well:
But not so Citizen a wanton, as
To seem to die, ere sick: So please you, leave me,
Stick to your Journal course: the breach of Custom,
Is breach of all. I am ill, but your being by me
Cannot amend me. Society, is no comfort
To one not sociable: I am not very sick,
Since I can reason of it: pray you trust me here,
I will rob none but myself, and let me die
Stealing so poorly.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I love thee: I have spoke it,
How much the quantity, the weight as much,
As I do love my Father.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What? How? how?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: If it be sin to say so (Sir) I yoke me
In my good Brothers fault: I know not why
I love this youth, and I have heard you say,
Love's reason is, without reason. The Beer at door,
And a demand who is it shall die, I would say
My Father, not this youth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O noble strain!
O worthiness of Nature, breed of Greatness!
Cowards father Cowards, and Base things Sire Base;
Nature hath Meal, and Bran; Contempt, and Grace.
I am not their Father, yet who this should be,
Doth miracle itself, loved before me.
It is the ninth hour of the Morn.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Brother, farewell.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I wish ye sport.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: You health. ~~ So please you Sir.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: These are kind Creatures.
Gods, what lies I have heard:
Our Courtiers say, all is savage, but at Court;
Experience, o thou disproovest Report.
The imperious Seas breeds Monsters; for the Dish,
Poor Tributary Rivers, as sweet Fish:
I am sick still, heartsick; Pisanio,
I will now taste of thy Drug.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I could not stir him:
He said he was gentle, but unfortunate;
Dishonestly afflicted, but yet honest.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Thus did he answer me: yet said hereafter,
I might know more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To; the Field, to the Field:
We will leave you for this time, go in, and rest.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: We will not be long away.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray be not sick,
For you must be our Housewife.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Well, or ill,
I am bound to you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And shalt be ever.
This youth, however distressed, appears he hath had
Good Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: How Angel-like he sings?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: But his neat Cookery?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: He cut our Roots in Characters,
And sauced our Broths, as Iuno had been sick,
And he her Dieter.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Nobly he yokes
A smiling, with a sigh; as if the sigh
Was that it was, for not being such a Smile:
The Smile, mocking the Sigh, that it would fly
From so divine a Temple, to commix
With winds, that Sailors rail at.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I do note,
That grief and patience rooted in them both,
Mingle their spurs together.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Grow patient,
And let the stinking-Elder (Grief) untwine
His perishing root, with the increasing Vine.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is great morning. Come away: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I cannot find those Runagates, that Villain
Hath mocked me. I am faint.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Those Runagates?
Means he not us? I partly know him, it is
Cloten, the Son of the Queen. I fear some Ambush:
I saw him not these many years, and yet
I know it is he: We are held as outlaws: Hence.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: He is but one: you, and my Brother search
What Companies are near : pray you away,
Let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Soft, what are you
That fly me thus? Some villain-Mountainers?
I have heard of such. What Slave art thou?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: A thing
More slavish did I never, than answering
A Slave without a knock.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou art a Robber,
A Law-breaker, a Villain: yield thee Thief.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: To who? to thee? What art thou? Have not I
An arm as big as thine? A heart, as big:
Thy words I grant are bigger: for I wear not
My Dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art:
Why I should yield to thee?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou Villain base,
Knowest me not by my Clothes?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: No, nor thy Taylor, Rascal:
Who is thy Grandfather? He made those clothes,
Which (as it seems) make thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thou precious Varlet,
My Taylor made them not.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Hence then, and thank
The man that gave them thee. Thou art some Fool,
I am loath to beat thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou injurious Thief,
Hear but my name, and tremble.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Cloten, thou Villain.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Cloten, thou double Villain be thy name,
I cannot tremble at it, were it Toad, or Adder, Spider,
It would move me sooner.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: To thy further fear,
Nay, to thy mere Confusion, thou shalt know
I am Son to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I am sorry for it: not seeming
So worthy as thy Birth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Art not afeared?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Those that I reverence, those I fear: the Wise:
At Fools I laugh: not fear them.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Die the death:
When I have slain thee with my proper hand,
I will follow those that even now fled hence:
And on the Gates of Luds-Towne set your heads:
Yield Rustic Mountaineer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No Company is abroad?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: None in the world: you did mistake him sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I cannot tell: Long is it since I saw him,
But Time hath nothing blurred those lines of Favour
Which then he wore: the snatches in his voice,
And burst of speaking were as his: I am absolute
It was very Cloten.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: In this place we left them;
I wish my Brother make good time with him,
You say he is so fell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Being scarce made up,
I mean to man; he had not apprehension
Of roaring terrors: For defect of judgment
Is oft the cause of Fear.
But see thy Brother.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: This Cloten was a Fool, an empty purse,
There was no money in it: Not Hercules
Could have knocked out his Brains, for he had none:
Yet I not doing this, the Fool had borne
My head, as I do his.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I am perfect what: cut off one Clotens head,
Son to the Queen (after his own report)
Who called me Traitor, Mountaineer, and swore
With his own single hand he would take us in,
Displace our heads, where (thanks the Gods) they grow
And set them on Luds-Towne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We are all undone.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Why, worthy Father, what have we to lose,
But that he swore to take our Lives? the Law
Protects not us, then why should we be tender,
To let an arrogant piece of flesh threat us?
Play Judge, and Executioner, all himself?
For we do fear the Law. What company
Discover you abroad?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No single soul
Can we set eye on: but in all safe reason
He must have some Attendants. Though his Honour
Was nothing but mutation, aye, and that
From one bad thing to worse: Not Frenzy,
Not absolute madness could so far have raved
To bring him here alone: although perhaps
It may be heard at Court, that such as we
Cave here, hunt here, are Outlaws, and in time
May make some stronger head, the which he hearing,
(As it is like him) might break out, and swear
He would fetch us in, yet is it not probable
To come alone, either he so undertaking,
Or they so suffering: then on good ground we fear,
If we do fear this Body hath a tail
More perilous than the head.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Let Ordinance
Come as the Gods fore-say it: howsoever,
My Brother hath done well.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had no mind
To hunt this day: The Boy Fideles sickness
Did make my way long forth.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: With his own Sword,
Which he did wave against my throat, I have taken
His head from him: I will throw it into the Creek
Behind our Rock, and let it to the Sea,
And tell the Fishes, he is the Queens Son, Cloten,
That is all I reek.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I fear it will be revenged:
Would (Polidore) thou hadst not done it: though valour
Becomes thee well enough.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Would I had done it:
So the Revenge alone pursued me: Polidore
I love thee brotherly, but envy much
Thou hast robbed me of this deed: I would Revenges
That possible strength might meet, wold seek us through
And put us to our answer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Well, it is done:
We will hunt no more today, nor seek for danger
Where there is no profit. I prithee to our Rock,
You and Fidele play the Cooks: I will stay
Till hasty Polidore return, and bring him
To dinner presently.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Poor sick Fidele.
I will willingly to him, to gain his colour,
I would let a parish of such Clotens blood,
And praise myself for charity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O thou Goddess,
Thou divine Nature; thou thyself thou blazonest
In these two Princely Boys: they are as gentle
As Zephyrs blowing below the Violet,
Not wagging his sweet head; and yet, as rough
(Their Royal blood enchafed) as the rudest wind,
That by the top doth take the Mountain Pine,
And make him stoop to the Vale. It is wonder
That an invisible instinct should frame them
To Royalty unlearned, Honour untaught,
Civility not seen from other: valour
That wildly grows in them, but yields a crop
As if it had been sowed: yet still it is strange
What Clotens being here to us portends,
Or what his death will bring us.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Where is my Brother?
I have sent Clotens Clot-pole down the stream,
In Embassy to his Mother; his Body is hostage
For his return.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My ingenuous Instrument,
(Hark Polidore) it sounds: but what occasion
Hath Cadwal now to give it motion? Hark.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Is he at home?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He went hence even now.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: What does he mean?
Since death of my dearest Mother
It did not speak before. All solemn things
Should answer solemn Accidents. The matter?
Triumphs for nothing, and lamenting Toys,
Is jollity for Apes, and grief for Boys.
Is Cadwall mad?

div2.stage:
Enter Aruiragus, with Imogen dead, bearing
her in his Armes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Look, here he comes,
And brings the dire occasion in his Arms,
Of what we blame him for.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: The Bird is dead
That we have made so much of. I had rather
Have skipped from sixteen years of Age, to sixty:
To have turned my leaping time into a Crutch,
Than have seen this.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: O sweetest, fairest Lily:
My Brother wears thee not the one half so well,
As when thou grewest thyself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O Melancholy,
Whoever yet could sound thy bottom? Find
The Ooze, to show what Coast thy sluggish care
Mightst easiliest harbour in. Thou blessed thing,
Jove knows what man thou mightst have made: but aye,
Thou diedest a most rare Boy, of Melancholy.
How found you him?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Stark, as you see:
Thus smiling, as some Fly had tickled slumber,
Not as deaths dart being laughed at: his right Cheek
Reposing on a Cushion.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: On the floor:
His arms thus leagued, I thought he slept, and put
My clouted Brogues from off my feet, whose rudeness
Answered my steps too loud.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Why, he but sleeps:
If he be gone, he will make his Grave, a Bed:
With female Fairies will his Tomb be haunted,
And Worms will not come to thee.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: With fairest Flowers
Whilst Summer lasts, and I live here, Fidele,
I will sweeten thy sad grave: thou shalt not lack
The Flower that is like thy face. Pale-Primrose, nor
The azured Hare-Bell, like thy Veins: no, nor
The leaf of Eglantine, whom not to slander,
Out-sweetened not thy breath: the Raddocke would
With Charitable bill (O bill sore shaming
Those rich-left-heirs, that let their Fathers lie
Without a Monument) bring thee all this,
Yea, and furred Moss besides. When Flowers are none
To winter-ground thy Coarse ~~

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Prithee have done,
And do not play in Wench-like words with that
Which is so serious. Let us bury him,
And not protract with admiration, what
Is now due debt. To the grave.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Say, where shall us lay him?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: By good Euriphile, our Mother.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Be it so:
And let us (Polidore) though now our voices
Have got the mannish crack, sing him to the ground
As once to our Mother: use like note, and words,
Save that Euriphile, must be Fidele.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Cadwall,
I cannot sing: I will weep, and word it with thee;
For Notes of sorrow, out of tune, are worse
Than Priests, and Phanes that lie.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: We will speak it then.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Great griefs I see medicine the less: For Cloten
Is quite forgot. He was a Queens Son, Boys,
And though he came our Enemy, remember
He was paid for that: though mean, and mighty rotting
Together have one dust, yet Reverence
(That Angel of the world) doth make distinction
Of place betweene high, and low. Our Foe was Princely,
And though you took his life, as being our Foe,
Yet bury him, as a Prince.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Pray you fetch him hither,
Thersites body is as good as Aiax,
When neither are alive.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: If you will go fetch him,
We will say our Song the whilst: Brother begin.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Nay Cadwall, we must lay his head to the East,
My Father hath a reason for it.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: It is true.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Come on then, and remove him.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: So, begin.

sp.speaker: Guid..

l.emph: Fear no more the heat of the Sun,
Thou thy worldly task hast done,
Home art gone, and taken thy wages.
Golden Lads, and Girls all must,

sp.l: As Chimney-Sweepers come to dust.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Fear no more the frown of the Great,
Thou art past the Tyrants stroke,
Care no more to cloth and eat,
To thee the Reed is as the Oak:
The Sceptre, Learning, Physic must,
All follow this and come to dust.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Fear no more the Lightning flash.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Nor the all-dreaded Thunderstorm.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Fear not Slander, Censure rash.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Thou hast finished Joy and moan.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: All Lovers young, all Lovers must,
Consign to thee and come to dust.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: No Exorciser harm thee,

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Nor no witch-craft charm thee.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Ghost unlaid forbear thee.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Nothing ill come near thee.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Quiet consummation have,
And renowned be thy grave.

div2.stage: Enter Belarius with the body of Cloten.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: We have done our obsequies:
Come lay him down.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here is a few Flowers, but about midnight more:
The herbs that have on them cold dew of the night
Are strewings fittest for Graves: upon their Faces.
You were as Flowers, now withered: even so
These Herbelets shall, which we upon you strew.
Come on, away, apart upon our knees:
The ground that gave them first, has them again:
Their pleasures here are past, so are their pain.
Yes Sir, to Milford-Hauen, which is the way?
I thank you: by yond bush? pray how far thither?
Od's pittikins: can it be six mile yet?
I have gone all night: I'faith, I will lie down, and sleep.
But soft; no Bedfellow? O Gods, and Goddesses!
These Flowers are like the pleasures of the World;
This bloody man the care of it. I hope I dream:
For so I thought I was a Cave-keeper,
And Cook to honest Creatures. But it is not so:
It was but a bolt of nothing, shot at nothing,
Which the Brain makes of Fumes. Our very eyes,
Are sometimes like our Judgments, blind. Good faith
I tremble still with fear: but if there be
Yet left in Heaven, as small a drop of pity
As a Wrens eye; feared Gods, a part of it.
The Dream is here still: even when I wake it is
Without me, as within me: not imagined, felt.
A headless man? The Garments of Posthumus?
I know the shape of his Leg: this is his Hand:
His Foot Mercurial: his martial Thigh
The brawns of Hercules: but his Jovial face ~~
Murther in heaven? How? it is gone. Pisanio,
All Curses madded Hecuba gave the Greeks,
And mine to boot, be darted on thee: thou
Conspired with that Irregulous devil Cloten,
Hath here cut off my Lord. To write, and read,
Be henceforth treacherous. Damned Pisanio,
Hath with his forged Letters (damned Pisanio)
From this most bravest vessel of the world
Struck the main top! O Posthumus, alas,
Where is thy head? where is that? Aye me! where is that?
Pisanio might have killed thee at the heart,
And left this head on. How should this be, Pisanio?
It is he, and Cloten: Malice, and Lucre in them
Have laid this Woe here. O it is pregnant, pregnant!
The Drug he gave me, which he said was precious
And Cordial to me, have I not found it
Murderous to the Senses? That confirms it home:
This is Pisanio's deed, and Cloten: O!
Give colour to my pale cheek with thy blood,
That we the horrider may seem to those
Which chance to find us. O, my Lord! my Lord!

div2.stage: Enter Lucius, Captaines, and a Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: To them, the Legions garrisoned in Gallia
After your will, have crossed the Sea, attending
You here at Milford-Hauen, with your Ships:
They are here in readiness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But what from Rome?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The Senate hath stirred up the Confiners,
And Gentlemen of Italy, most willing Spirits,
That promise Noble Service: and they come
Under the Conduct of bold Iachimo,
Syenna's Brother.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When expect you them?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: With the next benefit of the wind.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This forwardness
Makes our hopes fair. Command our present numbers
Be mustered: bid the Captains look to it. Now Sir,
What have you dreamed of late of this wars purpose.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: Last night, the very Gods showed me a
vision
(I fast, and prayed for their Intelligence) thus:
I saw Jove's Bird, the Roman Eagle winged
From the spongy South, to this part of the West,
There vanished in the Sun-beams, which portends
(Unless my sins abuse my Divination)
Success to the Roman host.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dream often so,
And never false. Soft ho, what trunk is here?
Without his top? The ruin speaks, that sometime
It was a worthy building. How? a Page?
Or dead, or sleeping on him? But dead rather:
For Nature doth abhor to make his bed
With the defunct, or sleep upon the dead.
Let us see the Boys face.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: He is alive my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: He will then instruct us of this body: Young one,
Inform us of thy Fortunes, for it seems
They crave to be demanded: who is this
Thou makest thy bloody Pillow? Or who was he
That (otherwise than noble Nature did)
Hath altered that good Picture? What is thy interest
In this sad wrack? How came it? Who is it?
What art thou?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I am nothing; or if not,
Nothing to be were better: This was my Master,
A very valiant Britaine, and a good,
That here by Mountaineers lies slain: Alas,
There is no more such Masters: I may wander
From East to Occident, cry out for Service,
Try many, all good: serve truly: never
Find such another Master.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alack, good youth:
Thou move no less with thy complaining, than
Thy Master in bleeding: say his name, good Friend.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Richard du Champ: If I do lie, and do
No harm by it, though the Gods hear, I hope
They will pardon it. Say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thy name?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Fidele Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou dost approve thyself the very same:
Thy Name well fits thy Faith; thy Faith, thy Name:
Wilt take thy chance with me? I will not say
Thou shalt be so well mastered, but be sure
No less beloved. The Roman Emperors Letters
Sent by a Consul to me, should not sooner
Than thine own worth prefer thee: Go with me.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I will follow Sir. But first, if it please the Gods,
I will hide my Master from the Flies, as deep
As these poor Pickaxes can dig: and when
With wild wood-leaves and weeds, I have strewed his grave
And on it said a Century of prayers
(Such as I can) twice over, I will weep, and sigh,
And leaving so his service, follow you,
So please you entertain me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Aye good youth,
And rather Father thee, than Master thee: My Friends,
The Boy hath taught us manly duties: Let us
Find out the prettiest Daisied-Plot we can,
And make him with our Pikes and Partisans
A Grave: Come, Arm him: Boy he is preferred
By thee, to us, and he shall be interred
As Soldiers can. Be cheerful; wipe thine eyes,
Some Falls are means the happier to arise.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Again: and bring me word how it is with her,
A Fever with the absence of her Son;
A madness, of which her life is in danger: Heavens,
How deeply you at once do touch me. Imogen,
The great part of my comfort, gone: My Queen
Upon a desperate bed, and in a time
When fearful Wars point at me: Her Son gone,
So needful for this present? It strikes me, past
The hope of comfort. But for thee, Fellow,
Who needs must know of her departure, and
Dost seem so ignorant, we will enforce it from thee
By a sharpe Torture.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Sir, my life is yours,
I humbly set it at your will: But for my Mistress,
I nothing know where she remains: why gone,
Nor when she purposes return. Beseech your Highness,
Hold me your loyal Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Good my Liege,
The day that she was missing, he was here;
I dare be bound he is true, and shall perform
All parts of his subjection loyally. For Cloten,
There wants no diligence in seeking him,
And will no doubt be found.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: The time is troublesome:
We will slip you for a season, but our jealousy
Does yet depend.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: So please your Majesty,
The Roman Legions, all from Gallia drawn,
Are landed on your Coast, with a supply
Of Roman Gentlemen, by the Senate sent.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Now for the Counsel of my Son and Queen,
I am amazed with matter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Good my Liege,
Your preparation can affront no less
Than what you hear of. Come more, for more you are ready:
The want is, but to put those Powers in motion,
That long to move.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I thank you: let us withdraw
And meet the Time, as it seeks us. We fear not
What can from Italy annoy us, but
We grieve at chances here. Away.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I heard no Letter from my Master, since
I wrote him Imogen was slain. It is strange:
Nor hear I from my Mistress, who did promise
To yield me often tidings. Neither know I
What is betide to Cloten, but remain
Perplexed in all. The Heavens still must work:
Wherein I am false, I am honest: not true, to be true.
These present wars shall find I love my Country,
Even to the note of the King, or I will fall in them:
All other doubts, by time let them be cleared,
Fortune brings in some Boats, that are not steered.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: The noise is round about us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let us from it.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: What pleasure Sir, we find in life, to lock it
From Action, and Adventure.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Nay, what hope
Have we in hiding us? This way the Romans
Must, or for Britaines slay us, or receive us
For barbarous and unnatural Revolts
During their use, and slay us after.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sons,
We will higher to the Mountains, there secure us.
To the Kings party there is no going: newness
Of Clotens death (we being not known, nor mustered
Among the Bands) may drive us to a render
Where we have lived; and so extort from us that
Which we have done, whose answer would be death
Drawn on with Torture.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: This is (Sir) a doubt
In such a time, nothing becoming you,
Nor satisfying us.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: It is not likely,
That when they hear their Roman horses neigh,
Behold their quartered Fires; have both their eyes
And ears so cloyed importantly as now,
That they will waste their time upon our note,
To know from whence we are.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O, I am known
Of many in the Army: Many years
(Though Cloten then but young) you see, not wore him
From my remembrance. And besides, the King
Hath not deserved my Service, nor your Loves,
Who find in my Exile, the want of Breeding;
The certainty of this heard life, aye hopeless
To have the courtesy your Cradle promised,
But to be still hot Summers Tanlings, and
The shrinking Slaves of Winter.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Than be so,
Better to cease to be. Pray Sir, to the Army:
I, and my Brother are not known; yourself
So out of thought, and thereto so overgrown,
Cannot be questioned.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: By this Sun that shines
I will thither: What thing is it, that I never
Did see man die, scarce ever looked on blood,
But that of Coward Hares, hot Goats, and Venison?
Never bestrid a Horse save one, that had
A Rider like myself, who never wore Rowel,
Nor Iron on his heel? I am ashamed
To look upon the holy Sun, to have
The benefit of his blessed Beams, remaining
So long a poor unknown.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: By heavens I will go,
If you will bless me Sir, and give me leave,
I will take the better care: but if you will not,
The hazard therefore due fall on me, by
The hands of Romans.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: So say I, Amen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No reason I (since of your lives you set
So slight a valuation) should reserve
My cracked one to more care. Have with you Boys:
If in your Country wars you chance to die,
That is my Bed too (Lads) and there I will lie.
Lead, lead; the time seems long, their blood thinks scorn
Till it fly out, and show them Princes born.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Yea bloody cloth, I will keep thee: for I am wished
Thou shouldst be coloured thus. You married ones,
If each of you should take this course, how many
Must murther Wives much better than themselves
For wrying but a little? O Pisanio,
Every good Servant does not all Commands:
No Bond, but to do just ones. Gods, if you
Should have 'tane vengeance on my faults, I never
Had lived to put on this: so had you saved
The noble Imogen, to repent, and struck
Me (wretch) more worth your Vengeance. But alack,
You snatch some hence for little faults; that is love
To have them fall no more: you some permit
To second ills with ills, each elder worse,
And make them dread it, to the doers thrift.
But Imogen is your own, do your best wills,
And make me blessed to obey. I am brought hither
Among the Italian Gentry, and to fight
Against my Ladies Kingdom: It is enough
That (Britaine) I have killed thy Mistress: Peace,
I will give no wound to thee: therefore good Heavens,
Hear patiently my purpose. I will disrobe me
Of these Italian weeds, and suite myself
As does a Britaine Peasant: so I will fight
Against the part I come with: so I will die
For thee (O Imogen) even for whom my life
Is every breath, a death: and thus, unknown,
Pitied, nor hated, to the face of peril
Myself I will dedicate. Let me make men know
More valour in me, than my habits show.
Gods, put the strength of the Leonati in me:
To shame the guise of the world, I will begin,
The fashion less without, and more within.

div2.head: Scena Secunda.
div2.stage:
Enter Lucius, Iachimo, and the Romane Army at one doore:
and the Britaine Army at another: Leonatus Posthumus
following like a poor Soldier. They march over, and go
out. Then enter again in Skirmish Iachimo and Posthumus:
he vanquishes and disarmeth Iachimo, and then
leaves him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: The heaviness and guilt within my bosom,
Takes off my manhood: I have belied a Lady,
The Princess of this Country; and the air of it
Revengingly enfeebles me, or could this Carl,
A very drudge of Natures, have subdued me
In my profession? Knighthoods, and Honours born
As I wear mine) are titles but of scorn.
If that thy Gentry (Britaine) go before
This Lout, as he exceeds our Lords, the odds
Is, that we scarce are men, and you are Goddess.

div2.stage:
The Battaile continues, the Britaines fly, Cymbeline is
taken: Then enter to his rescue, Bellarius, Guiderius
and Aruiragus.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stand, stand, we have the advantage of the ground,
The Lane is guarded: Nothing routs us, but
The villainy of our fears.

sp.speaker: Gui. Arui.
sp.l: Stand, stand, and fight.

div2.stage:
Enter Posthumus, and seconds the Britaines. They Rescue
Cymbeline, and Exeunt.
Then enter Lucius, Iachimo, and Imogen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Away boy from the Troops, and save thyself:
For friends kill friends, and the disorder is such
As war were hoodwinked.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: It is their fresh supplies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is a day turned strangely: or betimes
Let us reinforce, or fly.

div2.head: Scena Tertia.
div2.stage: Enter Posthumus, and a Britaine Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Camest thou from where they made the stand?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I did,
Though you it seems come from the Fliers?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: No blame be to you Sir, for all was lost,
But that the Heavens fought: the King himself
Of his wings destitute, the Army broken,
And but the backs of Britaines seen; all flying
Through a strait Lane, the Enemy full-hearted,
Lolling the Tongue with slaughtering: having work
More plentiful, than Tools todo it: struck down
Some mortally, some slightly touched, some falling
Merely through fear, that the strait pass was dammed
With deadmen, hurt behind, and Cowards living
To die with lengthened shame.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Where was this Lane?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Close by the battle, ditched, and walled with turf,
Which gave advantage to an ancient Soldier
(An honest one I warrant) who deserved
So long a breeding, as his white beard came to,
In doing this for his Country. Athwart the Lane,
He, with two striplings (Lads more like to run
The Country base, than to commit such slaughter,
With faces fit for Masks, or rather fairer
Than those for preservation cased, or shame)
Made good the passage, cried to those that fled.
Our Britaines hearts die flying, not our men,
To darkness fleet souls that fly backwards; stand,
Or we are Romans, and will give you that
Like beasts, which you shun beastly, and may save
But to look back in frown: Stand, stand. These three,
Three thousand confident, in act as many:
For three performers are the File, when all
The rest do nothing. With this word stand, stand,
Accommodated by the Place; more Charming
With their own Nobleness, which could have turned
A Distaff, to a Lance, gilded pale looks;
Part shame, part spirit renewed, that some turned coward
But by example (O a sin in War,
Damned in the first beginners) gan to look
The way that they did, and to grin like Lions
Upon the Pikes of the Hunters. Then began
A stop in the Chaser; a Retire: Anon
A Rout, confusion thick: forthwith they fly
Chickens, the way which they stopped Eagles: Slaves
The strides the Victors made: and now our Cowards
Like Fragments in hard Voyages became
The life of the need: having found the back door open
Of the unguarded hearts: heavens, how they wound,
Some slain before some dying; some their Friends
Overborne in the former wave, ten chased by one,
Are now each one the slaughter-man of twenty:
Those that would die, or ever resist, are grown
The mortal bugs of the Field.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: This was strange chance:
A narrow Lane, an old man, and two Boys.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Nay, do not wonder at it: you are made
Rather to wonder at the things you hear,
Than to work any. Will you Rime upon it,
And vent it for a Mockery? Here is one:
"Two Boys, an Old man (twice a Boy) a Lane,
"Preserved the Britaines, was the Romans bane.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry Sir.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Lack, to what end?
Who dares not stand his Foe, I will be his Friend:
For if he will do, as he is made to do,
I know he will quickly fly my friendship too.
You have put me into Rime.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Farewell, you are angry.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Still going? This is a Lord: O Noble misery
To be in the Field, and ask what news of me:
Today, how many would have given their Honours
To have saved their Carcasses? Took heel todo it,
And yet died too. I, in mine own woe charmed
Could not find death, where I did hear him groan,
Nor feel him where he struck. Being an ugly Monster,
It is strange he hides him in fresh Cups, soft Beds,
Sweet words; or hath more ministers than we
That draw his knives in the War. Well I will find him:
For being now a Favourer to the Britaine,
No more a Britaine, I have resumed again
The part I came in. Fight I will no more,
But yield me to the veriest Hind, that shall
Once touch my shoulder. Great the slaughter is
Here made by the Roman; great the Answer be
Britaines must take. For me, my Ransom is death,
On either side I come to spend my breath;
Which neither here I will keep, nor bear again,
But end it by some means for Imogen.
Great Iupiter be praised, Lucius is taken,
It is thought the old man, and his sons, were Angels.
There was a fourth man, in a silly habit,
That gave the Affront with them.
So it is reported:
But none of them can be found. Stand, who is there?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: A Roman,
Who had not now been drooping here, if Seconds
Had answered him.
Lay hands on him: a Dog,
A leg of Rome shall not return to tell
What Crows have pecked them here: he brags his service
As if he were of note: bring him to the King.

div2.stage:
Enter Cymbeline, Belarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus, Pisanio, and
Romane Captiues. The Captaines present Posthumus to
Cymbeline, who deliuers him ouer to a Gaoler.

div2.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.l: You shall not now be stolen,
You have locks upon you:
So graze, as you find Pasture.

sp.speaker: 2. Gao.
sp.l: Aye, or a stomach.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Most welcome bondage; for thou art a way
(I think) to liberty: yet am I better
Than one that is sick of the Gout, since he had rather
Groan so in perpetuity, than be cured
By the sure Physician, Death; who is the key
To unbar these Locks. My Conscience, thou art fettered
More than my shanks, and wrists: you good Gods give me
The penitent Instrument to pick that Bolt,
Than free forever. Is it enough I am sorry?
So Children temporal Fathers do appease;
Gods are more full of mercy. Must I repent,
I cannot do it better than in Gyves,
Desired, more than constrained, to satisfy
If of my Freedom it is the main part, take
No stricter render of me, than my All.
I know you are more clement than vile men,
Who of their broken Debtors take a third,
A sixth, a tenth, letting them thrive again
On their abatement; that is not my desire.
For Imogens dear life, take mine, and though
It is not so dear, yet it is a life; you coined it,
betweene man, and man, they weigh not every stamp:
Though light, take Pieces for the figures sake,
(You rather) mine being yours: and so great Powers,
If you will take this Audit, take this life,
And cancel these cold Bonds. O Imogen,
I will speak to thee in silence.

div2.stage:
Solemne Musicke. Enter (as in an Apparation) Sicillius Leonatus,
Father to Posthumus, an old man, attyred like a warriour,
leading in his hand an ancient Matron (his wife, and
Mother to Posthumus) with Musicke before them. Then
after other Musicke, followes the two young Leonati (Brothers
to Posthumus) with wounds as they died in the warrs.
They circle Posthumus round as he lies sleeping.

sp.speaker: Sicil.
sp.l: No more thou Thunder-Master
show thy spite, on Mortal Flies:
With Mars fall out with Iuno chide, that thy Adulteries
Rates, and Revenges.
Hath my poor Boy done aught but well,
whose face I never saw:
I died whilst in the Womb he stayed,
attending Natures Law.
Whose Father then (as men report,
thou Orphans Father art)
Thou shouldst have been, and shielded him,
from this earth-vexing smart.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Lucina lent not me her aid,
but took me in my Throws,
That from me was Posthumus ripped,
came crying amongst his Foes.
A thing of pity.

sp.speaker: Sicil
sp.l: Great Nature like his Ancestry,
moulded the stuff so fair:
That he deserved the praise of the World,
as great Sicilius heir.

sp.speaker: 1. Bro.
sp.l: When once he was mature for man,
in Britaine where was he
That could stand up his parallel?
Or fruitful object be?
In eye of Imogen, that best could deem
his dignity.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: With Marriage wherefore was he mocked
to be exiled, and thrown
From Leonati Seat, and cast from her,
his dearest one:
Sweet Imogen?

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.l: Why did you suffer Iachimo, slight thing of Italy,
To taint his Nobler heart and brain, with needless jealousy,
And to become the geek and scorn of the others villainy?

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: For this, from stiller Seats we came,
our Parents, and us twain,
That striking in our Countries cause,
fell bravely, and were slain,
Our Fealty, and Tenantius right, with Honour to maintain.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Like hardiment Posthumus hath
to Cymbeline performed:
Then Iupiter, you King of Gods, why hast you thus adjourned
The Graces for his Merits due, being all to dolours turned?

sp.speaker: Sicil.
sp.l: Thy Crystal window ope; look,
look out, no longer exercise
Upon a valiant Race, thy harsh, and potent injuries:

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Since (Iupiter) our Son is good,
take off his miseries.

sp.speaker: Sicil.
sp.l: Peep through thy Marble Mansion, help,
or we poor Ghosts will cry
To the shining Synod of the rest, against thy Deity.

sp.speaker: Brothers.
sp.l: Help (Iupiter) or we appeal,
and from thy justice fly.

div2.stage:
Iupiter descends in Thunder and Lightning, sitting vppon an
Eagle: hee throwes a Thunder-bolt. The Ghostes fall on
their knees.

sp.speaker: Iupiter.
sp.l: No more you petty Spirits of Region low
Offend our hearing: hush. How dare you Ghosts
Accuse the Thunderer, whose Bolt (you know)
Sky-planted, batters all rebelling Coasts.
Poor shadows of Elizium, hence, and rest
Upon your never-withering banks of Flowers.
Be not with mortal accidents oppressed,
No care of yours it is, you know it is ours.
Whom best I love, I cross; to make my gift
The more delayed, delighted. Be content,
Your low-laid Son, our Godhead will uplift:
His Comforts thrive, his Trials well are spent:
Our Jovial Star reigned at his Birth, and in
Our Temple was he married: Rise, and fade,
He shall be Lord of Lady Imogen,
And happier much by his Affliction made
This Tablet lay upon his Breast, wherein
Our pleasure, his full Fortune, doth confine,
And so away: no farther with your din
Express Impatience, lest you stir up mine:
Mount Eagle, to my Palace Crystalline.

sp.speaker: Sicil.
sp.l: He came in Thunder, his Celestial breath
Was sulphurous to smell: the holy Eagle
Stooped, as to foot us: his Ascension is
More sweet than our blessed Fields: his Royal Bird
Prunes the immortal wing, and cloys his Beak,
As when his God is pleased.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thanks Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.l: The Marble Pavement closes, he is entered
His radiant Roof: Away, and to be blessed
Let us with care perform his great behest.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Sleep, thou hast been a Grandsire, and begot
A Father to me: and thou hast created
A Mother, and two Brothers. But (o scorn)
Gone, they went hence so soon as they were born:
And so I am awake. Poor Wretches, that depend
On Greatness, Favour; Dream as I have done,
Wake, and find nothing. But (alas) I swerve:
Many Dream not to find, neither deserve,
And yet are steeped in Favours; so am I
That have this Golden chance, and know not why:
What Fairies haunt this ground? A Book? O rare one,
Be not, as is our fangled world, a Garment
Nobler than that it covers. Let thy effects
So follow, to be most unlike our Courtiers,
As good, as promise.

sp.p:
When as a Lions whelp, shall to himself unknown, without
seeking find, and be embraced by a piece of tender
Air: And when from a stately Cedar shall be lopped branches,
which being dead many years, shall after revive, be jointed to
the old Stock, and freshly grow, then shall Posthumus end his
miseries, Britaine be fortunate, and flourish in Peace and Plenty.

sp.l: It is still a Dream: or else such stuff as Madmen
Tongue, and brain not: either both, or nothing
Or senseless speaking, or a speaking such
As sense cannot untie. Be what it is,
The Action of my life is like it, which I will keep
If but for sympathy.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.l: Come Sir, are you ready for death?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Over-roasted rather: ready long ago.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
Hanging is the word, Sir, if you be ready for
that, you are well Cooked.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
So if I prove a good repast to the Spectators, the
dish pays the shot.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
A heavy reckoning for you Sir: But the comfort
is you shall be called to no more payments, fear no more
Tavern Bills, which are often the sadness of parting, as
the procuring of mirth: you come in faint for want of
meat, depart reeling with too much drink: sorry that
you have payed too much, and sorry that you are payed
too much: Purse and Brain, both empty: the Brain the
heavier, for being too light; the Purse too light, being
drawn of heaviness. O, of this contradiction you shall
now be quit: O the charity of a penny Cord, it sums
up thousands in a trice: you have no true Debtor, and
Creditor but it: of what is past, is, and to come, the discharge:
your neck (Sir) is Pen, Book, and Counters; so
the Acquittance follows.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I am merrier to die, than thou art to live.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
Indeed Sir, he that sleeps, feels not the
Tooth-Ache:
but a man that were to sleep your sleep, and a
Hangman to help him to bed, I think he would change
places with his Officer: for, look you Sir, you know not
which way you shall go.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Yes indeed do I, fellow.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
Your death has eyes in his head then: I have not
seen him so pictured: you must either be directed by
some that take upon them to know, or to take upon yourself that
which I am sure you do not know: or jump the
after-enquiry on your own peril: and how you shall
speed in your journeys end, I think you will never return
to tell one.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
I tell thee, Fellow, there are none want eyes, to
direct them the way I am going, but such as wink, and
will not use them.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
What an infinite mock is this, that a man
should
have the best use of eyes, to see the way of blindness: I
am sure hanging is the way of winking.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p:
Knock off his Manacles, bring your Prisoner to
the King.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
Thou bringest good news, I am called to be
made free.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p: I will be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
Thou shalt be then freer than a Gaoler; no bolts
for the dead.

sp.speaker: Gao.
sp.p:
Unless a man would marry a Gallows, and beget
young Gibbets, I never saw one so prone: yet on my
Conscience, there are verier Knaves desire to live, for all
he be a Roman; and there be some of them too that die
against their wills; so should I, if I were one. I would
we were all of one mind, and one mind good: O there
were desolation of Gaolers and Gallows: I speak against
my present profit, but my wish hath a preferment
in it.

div2.head: Scena Quinta.
div2.stage:
Enter Cymbeline, Bellarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus,
Pisanio, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Stand by my side you, whom the Gods have made
Preservers of my Throne: woe is my heart,
That the poor Soldier that so richly fought,
Whose rags, shamed gilded Arms, whose naked breast
Stepped before Targes of proof, cannot be found:
He shall be happy that can find him, if
Our Grace can make him so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I never saw
Such Noble fury in so poor a Thing;
Such precious deeds, in one that promised naught
But beggary, and poor looks.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: No tidings of him?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: He hath been searched among the dead, and living;
But no trace of him.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: To my grief, I am
The heir of his Reward, which I will add
To you (the Liver, Heart, and Brain of Britaine)
By whom (I grant) she lives. It is now the time
To ask of whence you are. Report it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sir,
In Cambria are we born, and Gentlemen:
Further to boast, were neither true, nor modest,
Unless I add, we are honest.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Bow your knees:
Arise my Knights of the Battle, I create you
Companions to our person, and will fit you
With Dignities becoming your estates.
There is business in these faces: why so sadly
Greet you our Victory? you look like Romans,
And not of the Court of Britaine.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Hail great King,
To sour your happiness, I must report
The Queen is dead.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Who worse than a Physician
Would this report become? But I consider,
By Medicine life may be prolonged, yet death
Will seize the Doctor too. How ended she?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: With horror, madly dying, like her life,
Which (being cruel to the world) concluded
Most cruel to herself. What she confessed,
I will report, so please you. These her Women
Can trip me, if I err, who with wet cheeks
Were present when she finished.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Prithee say.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: First, she confessed she never loved you: only
Affected Greatness got by you: not you:
Married your Royalty, was wife to your place:
Abhorred your person.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: She alone knew this:
And but she spoke it dying, I would not
Believe her lips in opening it. Proceed.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Your daughter, whom she bore in hand to love
With such integrity, she did confess
Was as a Scorpion to her sight, whose life
(But that her flight prevented it) she had
taken off by poison.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: O most delicate Fiend!
Who is it can read a Woman? Is there more?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: More Sir, and worse. She did confess she had
For you a mortal Mineral, which being took,
Should by the minute feed on life, and lingering,
By inches waste you. In which time, she purposed
By watching, weeping, tendance, kissing, to
Overcome you with her show; and in time
(When she had fitted you with her craft, to work
Her Son into the adoption of the Crown:
But failing of her end by his strange absence,
Grew shameless desperate, opened (in despite
Of Heaven, and Men) her purposes: repented
The evils she hatched, were not effected: so
Despairing, died.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Heard you all this, her Women?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: We did, so please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Mine eyes
Were not in fault, for she was beautiful:
Mine ears that hear her flattery, nor my heart,
That thought her like her seeming. It had been vicious
To have mistrusted her: yet (O my Daughter)
That it was folly in me, thou mayst say,
And prove it in thy feeling. Heaven mend all.
sp.stage:
Enter Lucius, Iachimo, and other Roman prisoners,
Leonatus behind, and Imogen.
sp.l: Thou comest not Caius now for Tribute, that
The Britaines have raced out, though with the loss
Of many a bold one: whose Kinsmen have made suite
That their good souls may be appeased, with slaughter
Of you their Captives, which ourself have granted,
So think of your estate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Consider Sir, the chance of War, the day
Was yours by accident: had it gone with us,
We should not when the blood was cool, have threatened
Our Prisoners with the Sword. But since the Gods
Will have it thus, that nothing but our lives
May be called ransom, let it come: Sufficeth,
A Roman, with a Romans heart can suffer:
Augustus lives to think on it: and so much
For my peculiar care. This one thing only
I will entreat, my Boy (a Britaine born)
Let him be ransomed: Never Master had
A Page so kind, so duteous, diligent,
So tender over his occasions, true,
So feat, so Nurse-like: let his virtue join
With my request, which I will make bold your Highness
Cannot deny: he hath done no Britaine harm,
Though he have served a Roman. Save him (Sir)
And spare no blood beside.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I have surely seen him:
His favour is familiar to me: Boy,
Thou hast looked thyself into my grace,
And art mine own. I know not why, wherefore,
To say, live boy: never thank thy Master, live;
And ask of Cymbeline what Boon thou wilt,
Fitting my bounty, and thy state, I will give it:
Yea, though thou do demand a Prisoner
The Noblest taken.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Highness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do not bid thee beg my life, good Lad,
And yet I know thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: No, no, alack,
There is other work in hand: I see a thing
Bitter to me, as death: your life, good Master,
Must shuffle for itself.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Boy disdains me,
He leaves me, scorns me: briefly die their joys,
That place them on the truth of Girls, and Boys.
Why stands he so perplexed?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: What wouldst thou Boy?
I love thee more, and more: think more and more
What is best to ask. Knowest him thou lookest on? speak
Wilt have him live? Is he thy Kin? thy Friend?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: He is a Roman, no more kin to me,
Than I to your Highness, who being born your vassal
Am something nearer.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Wherefore eyest him so?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I will tell you (Sir) in private, if you please
To give me hearing.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Aye, with all my heart,
And lend my best attention. What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Fidele Sir.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Thou art my good youth: my Page
I will be thy Master: walk with me: speak freely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is not this Boy revived from death?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: One Sand another
Not more resembles that sweet Rosie Lad:
Who died, and was Fidele: what think you?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: The same dead thing alive.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Peace, peace, see further: he eyes us not, forbear
Creatures may be alike: were it he, I am sure
He would have spoke to us.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: But we see him dead.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be silent: let us see further.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: It is my Mistress:
Since she is living, let the time run on,
To good, or bad.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Come, stand thou by our side,
Make thy demand aloud. Sir, step you forth,
Give answer to this Boy, and do it freely,
Or by our Greatness, and the grace of it
(Which is our Honour) bitter torture shall
Winnow the truth from falsehood. One speak to him.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: My boon is, that this Gentleman may render
Of whom he had this Ring.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: What is that to him?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: That Diamond upon your Finger, say
How came it yours?

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: Thou wilt torture me to leave unspoken, that
Which to be spoke, would torture thee.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: How? me?

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: I am glad to be constrained to utter that
Which torments me to conceal. By Villainy
I got this Ring: it was Leonatus Jewel,
Whom thou didst banish: and which more may grieve (thee,
As it doth me: a Nobler Sir, never lived
betwixt sky and ground. Wilt thou hear more my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: All that belongs to this.

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: That Paragon, thy daughter,
For whom my heart drops blood, and my false spirits
Quail to remember. Give me leave, I faint.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: My Daughter? what of her? Renew thy strength
I had rather thou shouldst live, while Nature will,
Than die ere I hear more: strive man, and speak.

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: Upon a time, unhappy was the clock
That struck the hour: it was in Rome, accursed
The Mansion where: it was at a Feast, o would
Our Viands had been poisoned (or at least
Those which I heaved to head:) the good Posthumus,
(What should I say? he was too good to be
Where ill men were, and was the best of all
Amongst the rarest of good ones) sitting sadly,
Hearing us praise our Loves of Italy
For Beauty, that made barren the swelled boast
Of him that best could speak: for Feature, laming
The Shrine of Venus, or straight-pight Minerua,
Postures, beyond brief Nature. For Condition,
A shop of all the qualities, that man
Loves woman for, besides that hook of Wiving,
Fairness, which strikes the eye.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I stand on fire. Come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: All too soon I shall,
Unless thou wouldst grieve quickly. This Posthumus,
Most like a Noble Lord, in love, and one
That had a Royal Lover, took his hint,
And (not dispraising whom we praised, therein
He was as calm as virtue) he began
His Mistress picture, which, by his tongue, being made,
And then a mind put in it, either our brags
Were cracked of Kitchen-Trulls, or his description
Proved us unspeaking sots.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Nay, nay, to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Iach.
sp.l: Your daughters Chastity, (there it begins)
He spake of her, as Dian had hot dreams,
And she alone, were cold: Whereat, I wretch
Made scruple of his praise, and wagered with him
Pieces of Gold, against this, which then he wore
Upon his honoured finger) to attain
In suite the place of his bed, and win this Ring
By hers, and mine Adultery: he (true Knight)
No lesser of her Honour confident
Than I did truly find her, stakes this Ring,
And would so, had it been a Carbuncle
Of Phoebus Wheel; and might so safely, had it
Been all the worth of his Car. Away to Britaine
Post I in this design: Well may you (Sir)
Remember me at Court, where I was taught
Of your chaste Daughter, the wide difference
betwixt Amorous, and Villainous. Being thus quenched
Of hope, not longing; mine Italian brain,
Gan in your duller Britaine operate
Most vilely: for my vantage excellent.
And to be brief, my practise so prevailed
That I returned with similar proof enough,
To make the Noble Leonatus mad,
By wounding his belief in her Renown,
With Tokens thus, and thus: averring notes
Of Chamber-hanging, Pictures, this her Bracelet
(O cunning how I got) nay some marks
Of secret on her person, that he could not
But think her bond of Chastity quite cracked,
I having 'tane the forfeit. Whereupon,
Methinks I see him now.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Aye so thou dost,
Italian Fiend. Aye me, most credulous Fool,
Egregious murtherer, Thief, anything
That is due to all the Villains past, in being
To come. O give me Cord, or knife, or poison,
Some upright Justicer. Thou King, send out
For Torturers ingenious: it is I
That all the abhorred things of the earth amend
By being worse than they. I am Posthumus,
That killed thy Daughter: Villain-like, I lie,
That caused a lesser villain than myself,
A sacrilegious Thief todo it. The Temple
Of Virtue was she; yea, and she herself.
Spit, and throw stones, cast mire upon me, set
The dogs of the street to bay me: every villain
Be called Posthumus Leonatus, and
Be villainy less than it was. O Imogen!
My Queen, my life, my wife: o Imogen,
Imogen, Imogen.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Peace my Lord, hear, hear.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Shall us have a play of this?
Thou scornful Page, there lie thy part.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, help,
Mine and your Mistress: O my Lord Posthumus,
You never killed Imogen till now: help, help,
Mine honoured Lady.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Does the world go round?

sp.speaker: Posth.
sp.l: How comes these staggers on me?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Wake my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: If this be so, the Gods do mean to strike me
To death, with mortal joy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How fares my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: O get thee from my sight,
Thou gavest me poison: dangerous Fellow hence,
Breath not where Princes are.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: The tune of Imogen.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lady, the Gods throw stones of sulphur on me, if
That box I gave you, was not thought by me
A precious thing, I had it from the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: New matter still.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: It poisoned me.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O Gods!
I left out one thing which the Queen confessed,
Which must approve thee honest. If Pasanio
Have (said she) given his Mistress that Confection
Which I gave him for Cordial, she is served,
As I would serve a Rat.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: What is this, Cornelius?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: The Queen (Sir) very oft importuned me
To temper poisons for her, still pretending
The satisfaction of her knowledge, only
In killing Creatures vile, as Cats and Dogs
Of no esteem. I dreading, that her purpose
Was of more danger, did compound for her
A certain stuff, which being taken, would cease
The present power of life, but in short time,
All Offices of Nature, should again
Do their due Functions. Have you taken of it?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Most like I did, for I was dead.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Boys, there was our error.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: This is sure Fidele.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Why did you throw your wedded Lady from you?
Think that you are upon a Rock, and now
Throw me again.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Hang there like fruit, my soul,
Till the Tree die.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: How now, my Flesh? my Child?
What, makest thou me a dullard in this Act?
Wilt thou not speak to me?

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: Your blessing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Though you did love this youth, I blame ye not,
You had a motive for it.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: My tears that fall
Prove holy-water on thee; Imogen,
Thy Mother is dead.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: I am sorry for it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: O, she was naught; and long of her it was
That we meet here so strangely: but her Son
Is gone, we know not how, nor where.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: My Lord,
Now fear is from me, I will speak troth. Lord Cloten
Upon my Ladies missing, came to me
With his Sword drawn, foamed at the mouth, and swore
If I discovered not which way she was gone,
It was my instant death. By accident,
I had a feigned Letter of my Masters
Then in my pocket, which directed him
To seek her on the Mountains near to Milford,
Where in a frenzy, in my Masters Garments
(Which he enforced from me) away he posts
With unchaste purpose, and with oath to violate
My Ladies honour, what became of him,
I further know not.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Let me end the Story: I slew him there.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Marry, the Gods forfend.
I would not thy good deeds, should from my lips
Pluck a hard sentence: Prithee valiant youth
Deny it again.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I have spoke it, and I did it.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: He was a Prince.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: A most incivil one. The wrongs he did me
Were nothing Prince-like; for he did provoke me
With Language that would make me spurn the Sea,
If it could so roar to me. I cut off his head,
And am right glad he is not standing here
To tell this tale of mine.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I am sorrow for thee:
By thine own tongue thou art condemned, and must
Endure our Law: Thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: That headless man I thought had been my Lord

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Bind the Offender,
And take him from our presence.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay, Sir King.
This man is better than the man he slew,
As well descended as thyself, and hath
More of thee merited, than a Band of Clotens
Had ever scar for. Let his Arms alone,
They were not born for bondage.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Why old Soldier:
Wilt thou undo the worth thou art unpaid for
By tasting of our wrath? How of descent
As good as we?

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: In that he spake too far.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: And thou shalt die for it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We will die all three,
But I will prove that two of us are as good
As I have given out him. My Sons, I must
For mine own part, unfold a dangerous speech,
Though happily well for you.

sp.speaker: Arui.
sp.l: Your danger is ours.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: And our good his.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have at it then, by leave
Thou haddest (great King) a Subject, who
Was called Belarius.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: What of him? He is a banished Traitor.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He it is, that hath
Assumed this age: indeed a banished man,
I know not how, a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Take him hence,
The whole world shall not save him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not too hot;
First pay me for the Nursing of thy Sons,
And let it be confiscate all, so soon
As I have received it.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Nursing of my Sons?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am too blunt, and saucy: here is my knee:
Ere I arise, I will prefer my Sons,
Then spare not the old Father. Mighty Sir,
These two young Gentlemen that call me Father,
And think they are my Sons, are none of mine,
They are the issue of your Loins, my Liege,
And blood of your begetting.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: How? my Issue.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So sure as you, your Fathers: I (old Morgan)
Am that Belarius, whom you sometime banished:
Your pleasure was my near offence, my punishment
Itself, and all my Treason that I suffered,
Was all the harm I did. These gentle Princes
(For such, and so they are) these twenty years
Have I trained up; those Arts they have, as I
Could put into them. My breeding was (Sir)
As your Highness knows: Their Nurse Euriphile
(Whom for the Theft I wedded) stole these Children
Upon my Banishment: I moved her to it,
Having received the punishment before
For that which I did then. Beaten for Loyalty,
Excited me to Treason. Their dear loss,
The more of you it was felt, the more it shaped
Unto my end of stealing them. But gracious Sir,
Here are your Sons again, and I must lose
Two of the sweetest Companions in the World.
The benediction of these covering Heavens
Fall on their heads like dew, for they are worthy
To in-lay Heaven with Stars.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Thou weepest, and speakest:
The Service that you three have done, is more
Unlike, than this thou tellest. I lost my Children,
If these be they, I know not how to wish
A pair of worthier Sons.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be pleased awhile;
This Gentleman, whom I call Polidore,
Most worthy Prince, as yours, is true Guiderius:
This Gentleman, my Cadwall, Aruiragus.
Your younger Princely Son, he Sir, was lapped
In a most curious Mantle, wrought by the hand
Of his Queen Mother, which for more probation
I can with ease produce.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Guiderius had
Upon his neck a Mole, a sanguine Star,
It was a mark of wonder.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is he,
Who hath upon him still that natural stamp:
It was wise Natures end, in the donation
To be his evidence now.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: O, what am I
A Mother to the birth of three? Never Mother
Rejoiced deliverance more: Blessed, pray you be,
That after this strange starting from your Orbs,
You may reign in them now: O Imogen,
Thou hast lost by this a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Imo.
sp.l: No, my Lord:
